metadata.title: Binary Rating Estimation with Graph Side Information
metadata.author: Kwangjun Ahn, Kangwook Lee, Hyunseung Cha, Changho Suh
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: Rich experimental evidences show that one can better estimate users’ unknown ratings with the aid of graph side information such as social graphs. However, the gain is not theoretically quantified. In this work, we study the binary rating estimation problem to understand the fundamental value of graph side information. Considering a simple correlation model between a rating matrix and a graph, we characterize the sharp threshold on the number of observed entries required to recover the rating matrix (called the optimal sample complexity) as a function of the quality of graph side information (to be detailed). To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to reveal how much the graph side information reduces sample complexity. Further, we propose a computationally efficient algorithm that achieves the limit. Our experimental results demonstrate that the algorithm performs well even with real-world graphs.

highlights: Recommender systems provide users with appropriate items based on their revealed preference such as ratings and like/dislikes
We intend to characterize the optimal sample complexity needed for rating matrix recovery in the presence of the graph side information
Denote by the optimal sample complexity the minimum number of observed ratings required for reliable recovery
We proposed an efficient rating estimation algorithm that provably achieves the optimal sample complexity
This paper comes with some limitations in characterizing sample complexity for more general models
It would be interesting to characterize the optimal sample for feature-based side information models [14, 45]

We intend to characterize the optimal sample complexity needed for rating matrix recovery in the presence of the graph side information
Denote by the optimal sample complexity the minimum number of observed ratings required for reliable recovery

We provide a theoretical performance guarantee of this algorithm under the model of interest: we prove that the algorithm reliably recovers the ratings as soon as sample complexity exceeds the optimal sample complexity

summary: Recommender systems provide users with appropriate items based on their revealed preference such as ratings and like/dislikes.
We intend to characterize the optimal sample complexity needed for rating matrix recovery in the presence of the graph side information.
Denote by the optimal sample complexity the minimum number of observed ratings required for reliable recovery.
This result suggests that the social graph information does not help rating recovery when the number of users is relatively smaller than th√at of item√s.
When 2n log n > 4γm log m, i.e., (1) is equal to γ−1n log n/( 1 − θ − θ)2, the result implies that the social graph information does help rating recovery.
Example 2 justifies the observation made by Jamali and Ester [26] that graph side information can help predict ratings for cold start users.
The efficacy of the information depends on its quality: When n2Is = o(n log n), social network is too noisy, and does not help rating recovery.
We propose an efficient rating estimation algorithm, which achieves the fundamental limit characterized in Theorem 1.

When the algorithm knows that the clusters are of equal size, we obtain the following refinement rule: we put user i to A, where j∗ = arg maxj∈[k] c1 · e {i}, A + Πi(u(j)) for some hyperparameter c1 > 0.
Note that this algorithm can be applied to a general setting where (i) rating type is not limited to binary; the number of clusters can be larger than 2; and the clusters are of unequal sizes.
With probability approaching 1 as n → ∞, the proposed algorithm with the knowledge that the two clusters are of equal size exactly recovers R under the settings
Theorem 2 implies that the proposed algorithm with proper hyperparameter choices achieves the fundamental limit in Theorem 1 except for the case of scarce social graph information (Is = O(1/n)).
The synthetic data is generated as per the model in Sec. 2.6 For each triple (p, α, β), an empirical success rate of the proposed algorithm is measured over 100 random trials.

Motivated by the lack of study in quantifying the value of social graph information in recommender systems, this work characterized the optimal sample complexity of the rating recovery problem with social graph information.
We proposed an efficient rating estimation algorithm that provably achieves the optimal sample complexity.
As in the case of community detection, sample complexity for partial recovery [3] might be more desirable in practice over our exact recovery setting
headline: We study the binary rating estimation problem to understand the fundamental value of graph side information
